attributes.title: Efficacy and safety of acupoint application therapy for allergic rhinitis: protocol for a systematic review and meta analysis
attributes.description: Allergic rhinitis (AR) is a common symptomatic, inflammatory and immunological disorder of nasal mucosa results from allergen exposure triggered IgE response. Epidemiology of allergic rhinitis varies according to different factors like genetic constitution, racial differences, socio-economic conditions, chances of exposure to different allergens, sex, growth stages. AR shows high prevalence among developed countries. AR is managed with first and second anti histamines (56%), intra nasal corticosteroids (25%) and mast cell stabilizers (19%). Prolonged usage of these medications is necessary in beating the disease as far as the recurrence is concerned. This may lead to numerous serious health hazards. Studies have shown that negative effects of sedative anti-histamines last to the succeeding day disturbing the day time performance. Traditional Chinese medicine in the treatment of allergic rhinitis has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on acupoint application therapy for allergic rhinitis. Therefore, research on it is needed.

q1.value: Qinxiu Zhang, Deyun Wang, Lei Cheng, Yan Ruan, Peng Liu, Kexin Hu, Xuanpu Gong, Jinhui Liu, Rongchang Feng, Jianying Gao, Hui Xie, Xinrong Li, Qinwei Fu

q2.value:
1. Acupoint application therapy is effective for treatment of patients with allergic rhinitis.
2. How does the efficacy of acupoint application therapy compare to that with acupuncture, Western medicine therapies alone, other TCM therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions? 
3. There are some moderating variables associated with treatment efficacy in studies of acupoint application therapy for patients with the allergic rhinitis.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q5.value:
Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer.
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer.
Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.

The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

question.value:
1. Anticipated start date: 11/04/2020;

2. Anticipated completion date: 03/06/2020;

3.Review question: ①.Is acupoint application therapy an effective treatment for patiens with allergic rhinitis?
                                  ②. How does the efficacy of acupoint application therapy compare to that with acupuncture, having western medicines, blank control, placebo control and other interventions?
                                  ③. What moderating variables are associated with treatment effectiveness in studies of acupoint application therapy for patients with allergic rhinitis? 

4. Searches: English databases including PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library and Chinese databases including CNKI, Wanfang, VIP databases will be searched. The research will start following the PRISMA protocol.
The terms used in the search will follow the rules of the Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) and the question that guided the search was based on the PICOS strategy (participants, interventions, comparison, results and studies). search strategy information can be found in the attached PDF document (link provided below).
One week will be allocated for data collection and one week for article analysis.
Retrieval time is from the inception dates of the databases to 24 Apri, 2020.
We also considered the alternative terms and spellings for keywords.
In addition, the references of initially included literature were traced back to achieve a comprehensive search. English and Chinese language were included.

5. Condition or domain being studied: Allergic rhinitis (AR) is a common symptomatic, inflammatory and immunological disorder of nasal mucosa results from allergen exposure triggered IgE response. Epidemiology of allergic rhinitis varies according to different factors like genetic constitution, racial differences, socio-economic conditions, chances of exposure to different allergens, sex, growth stages. AR shows high prevalence among developed countries. AR is managed with first and second anti histamines (56%), intra nasal corticosteroids (25%) and mast cell stabilizers (19%). Prolonged usage of these medications is necessary in beating the disease as far as the recurrence is concerned. This may lead to numerous serious health hazards. Studies have shown that negative effects of sedative anti-histamines last to the succeeding day disturbing the day time performance. Traditional Chinese medicine in the treatment of allergic rhinitis has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on acupoint application therapy for allergic rhinitis. Therefore, research on it is needed.

6.Participants/population: Participants with all types of allergic rhinitis (including intermittent allergic rhinitis and persistent allergic rhinitis) regardless of gender, age, etiology, ethnic group, severity, diagnosed with specific criteria (i.e. mention any one of criteria for diagnosis of allergic rhinitis) are eligible for inclusion. Complicated with asthma, nasosinusitis are excluded.

7. Intervention(s), exposure(s): Treatment of acupoint application therapy.

8. Comparator(s)/control: Including acupuncture, western medicines, blank control, placebo control and other interventions. Interventions in the experimental group were not included.

9. Types of study to be included: We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs), published and unpublished, in English and Chinese.

10. Main outcome(s): ①Total Nasal Symptom Score (TNSS) and four key symptoms' scores;
                                      ②Rhinitis Quality of Life Questionnaire (RQLQ); 
                                      ③VAS score;
                                      ④Total effective rate;
                                      ⑤Score for signs and symptoms;
                                      ⑥The improvement of disease classification.

11. Additional outcome(s): ① TNNSS;
                                                ②Laboratory index, eg. IgE, IL;
                                                ③Recurrence rate;
                                                ④Time when the symptoms disappear;
                                                ⑤Frequency of seizure;
                                                ⑥The case of drug reduction.

12. Data extraction (selection and coding): Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer.
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer.

13.Risk of bias (quality) assessment: Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.
The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

14. Strategy for data synthesis: Statistical analyses will be performed using RevMan 5.3 software (The Cochrane Collaboration).
- Pooled risk ratio (RR) with 95% confidence interval (CI) of dichotomous outcomes will be used to report effect estimate.
- Continuous data will be presented as mean difference (MD) with 95% CI. If different measurement scales are used, standardized mean difference (SMD) will be performed to analyze continuous data.
If required data are not reported, we will try to obtain data from corresponding author.
Heterogeneity will be assessed using both the χ² test and the I² statistic, and we will consider an I² value greater than 50% indicative of substantial heterogeneity.
- For I²<50%, a fixed-effect model is used.
- For I² >=50%, a random-effect model is applied.
If data permit, we plan to exclude some trials that contribuite most to the heterogeneity to see whether the result change or not.
We will also use a summary of findings table to present the main findings using GRADEpro software (The Cochrane Collaboration). Funnel plots will be generated to detect publication bias if more than 10 trials are identified to report the same outcomes. If appropriate, we will use cumulative meta-analyses. Results of meta-analyses will be visualized by forest plots. In addition, we will conduct trial sequential analysis to evaluate the meta-analyses for primary outcomes, which can reveal the required information size and potentially false results in a meta-analysis. Intention-to-treat analysis will be applied for primary outcome, if missing data from the original trials are available.

15. Analysis of subgroups or subsets: If data permitted, we plan to conduct subgroup analyses for different groups, including:
Different age of patients
Different severity of disease
Different regimen applied
Different treat time
Different acupoints selected
Combined with other interventions or not.

16. Type and method of review: intervention; Meta-analysis; Prevention; Systematic review.

17. Health area of the review: Complementary therapies; Allergy; Public health; ENT; 

18. Languages of the review: English and Chinese;

19. Dissemination plans: In addition to producing a report, a paper will be submitted to a journal in this field.

2.Participants/population: Participants with all types of allergic rhinitis (including intermittent allergic rhinitis and persistent allergic rhinitis) regardless of gender, age, etiology, ethnic group, severity, diagnosed with specific criteria (i.e. mention any one of criteria for diagnosis of allergic rhinitis) are eligible for inclusion. Complicated with asthma, nasosinusitis are excluded.

3. Intervention(s), exposure(s): Treatment of acupoint application therapy.

4. Comparator(s)/control: Including acupuncture, western medicines, blank control, placebo control and other interventions. Interventions in the experimental group were not included.

5. Types of study to be included: We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs), published and unpublished, in English and Chinese.

6. Data extraction (selection and coding): Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer.
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer.
registration_responses.q14.question: Not applicable.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Statistical analyses will be performed using RevMan 5.3 software (The Cochrane Collaboration).
- Pooled risk ratio (RR) with 95% confidence interval (CI) of dichotomous outcomes will be used to report effect estimate.
- Continuous data will be presented as mean difference (MD) with 95% CI. If different measurement scales are used, standardized mean difference (SMD) will be performed to analyze continuous data.
If required data are not reported, we will try to obtain data from corresponding author.
Heterogeneity will be assessed using both the χ² test and the I² statistic, and we will consider an I² value greater than 50% indicative of substantial heterogeneity.
- For I²<50%, a fixed-effect model is used.
- For I² >=50%, a random-effect model is applied.
If data permit, we plan to exclude some trials that contribuite most to the heterogeneity to see whether the result change or not.
We will also use a summary of findings table to present the main findings using GRADEpro software (The Cochrane Collaboration). Funnel plots will be generated to detect publication bias if more than 10 trials are identified to report the same outcomes. If appropriate, we will use cumulative meta-analyses. Results of meta-analyses will be visualized by forest plots. In addition, we will conduct trial sequential analysis to evaluate the meta-analyses for primary outcomes, which can reveal the required information size and potentially false results in a meta-analysis. Intention-to-treat analysis will be applied for primary outcome, if missing data from the original trials are available.

attributes.title: Curiosity and creativity - individual differences study

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun

q2.value: Ronja Müller-Späth, Elaura Dana Ott, Annika Weißner, Carina Warnstädt , Marie Hennecke

q3.value: This study was planned during a course at the University of Siegen. In this course, we were given information on the relation between affect and approach and avoidance goal orientations. We did not find any studies that tested the same effect we are expecting. Studies using similar components as we do led to the assumption that negative mood is related to an increased avoidance goal orientation whereas positive mood is related to an increased apporach goal orientation. The current study tests whether manipulating mood causes differences in approach and avoidance goal orientation.

q4.value:
In an achievement context, we suspect that participants in a positive mood will be higher in their approach motivation than participants in negative or neutral mood.
In contrast, we suspect that participant in a negative mood will be higher in their avoidance motivation than participants in positive or neutral mood.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The experiment consists of a between-subject design with 1 factor (mood) and 3 levels (positive and negative mood, as well as the control group).

q9.value: We will use a randomisation created by the tool "LimeSurvey", where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the three groups. To do that, the program randomly assigns the subject a number of one to three. Each of the numbers then represents one group and redirects the participant to the related version of the questionnaire.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited by sending a hyperlink that redirects them to LimeSurvey, where they can fill in our questionnaire. The link will be sent to private contacts as well as an official email-list including all psychology students at the University of Siegen. 
Psychology students will receive credit for their degree. All other participants are doing the questionnaire without being paid for it.
To be able to be included in our data, all participants are expected to understand the German language. This is a requirement we will not explicitly check in our study. 
Participants who are currently in a relationship will be excluded and redirected to a study created by our fellow students whose design requires all participants to be in a relationship.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 105 subjects. We are going to gather data up to our set stopping date in April.

q14.value:
We used the software G*Power to conduct a power analysis. We based our expected effect size on the study "Experimentally Manipulated Achievement Goal State Fluctuations
Regulate Self-Conscious Emotional Responses to Feedback" by A. L. Rebar and D. E. Conroy (2013). This was the only study we could find that included the variables we are measuring. 
Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .31 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.

q15.value: We are going to stop collecting data on the 6th of April 2020, no matter if our required sample size was reached or not.

question.value:
We are going to manipulate participants' mood by asking them to listen to mood-inflicting music. Depending on the experimental condition that participants have been randomly assigned to (positive mood/negative mood/control group), they are going to listen to either "West in Africa" (positive mood) or "Serial Killer" (negative mood), courtesy of John Bartmann (2018). Additionally, they are asked to remember and visualize a past event connected to the matching mood.
The control group is not given the task to listen to music. Instead, participants in this group are asked to describe their daily routine.

To measure participants' current mood we will use the PANAS (english original by Watson, Clark and Tellegen, 1988, german translation by Krohne, Egloff, Kohlmann and Tausch, 1996) with 20 items (rating scales from 1 = "not at all" to 5 = "very").
We will also measure participants' approach and avoidance goal orientation in an achievement context with an adapted version of the SELLMO (Spinath, Stiensmeier-Pelster, Schöne and Dickhäuser, 2002). This variable is the outcome variable in this design. It will be measured with 31 items (rating sale from 1 = "not at all" to 5 = "very").
The questions asked are chosen based on the participants' current occupational situation.

Manipulation check: We will use the PANAS to check whether the expected mood is detectable after the manipulation. Therefor we will globally determine if there is a significant effect of our mood manipulations in participants' approach and avoidance goal orientations. Furthermore, we will test whether the experimental groups differ significantly from the control group. 

Hypothesis check: We will use two single factorial between-subjects ANOVAs to globally determine if there is a significant effect of our mood manipulations in participants' approach and avoidance goal orientations.
In the next step, we will use the Dunnett post-hoc test to evaluate whether the experimental groups differ significantly from the control group. 
We expect to find a significantly higher approach motivation in the positive mood condition than in the control group as well as significantly higher avoidance motivation in the negative mood condition than in the control group.

We will also examine in an explorative manner whether there is a significant difference in means of the performance-avoidance motivation in the positive mood condition and the control group as well as the performance-approach motivation in the negative mood condition and the control group.

q22.value:
We included a manipulation check in our questionnaire. If the mood we wanted to induce is not detectable after the manipulation, the subject's data will be excluded from our analysis.
We expect a negative affect in the negative mood condition in contrast to the control group and the positive mood condition.
Likewise, we expect a positive affect in the positive mood condition in contrast to the control group and the negative mood condition.
If this can be shown, the manipulation was successful.

Another question is used to find out whether the subjects listened to the music presented to them. If it turns out they cannot answer this question, this will result in excluding their data as well.
In case a person under the age of 18 finishes the survey, the data will not be used either.
It is expected that all participants are able to use and understand the German language. This is a requirement we will not explicitly check in our study and therefore cannot be used as an exclusion criterion.

q23.value:
If a participant decides to stop the survey after answering some of our questions, their data will not be evaluated in our analysis.
If a participant answers less than 70% of any of the individual surveys (PANAS and SELLMO), their complete data will be excluded as well.
In any other cases, missing data will not result in exclusion from the study.

q24.value: We expect that positive mood influences avoidance motivation and negative mood influences approach motivation. We do not know which direction to expect from this. Therefore, we will also examine in an explorative manner if there is a difference in means between the performance-avoidance motivation in the positive mood condition and the performance-approach motivation in the negative mood condition.

attributes.title: Intuition not ideology: Rejection of false information not on the basis of partisan views, but because of intuitive gut feeling
attributes.description: This is a registration of study plans before data collection begins.

q1.value: Sharon Härtel, Magdalena Wischnewski, Nicole Krämer

q2.value:
H1: People with strong cognitive abilities can distinguish fake news from real news better. This means that a high CRT score correlates negatively with the perceived accuracy of fake news and positively with the perceived accuracy of real news. This is also the case if age, gender and educational level are kept constant.
H2: We expect the same effect when CRT is replaced with NfC (Need for Cognition): This means that a high NfC score correlates negatively with the perceived accuracy of fake news and positively with the perceived accuracy of real news. This is also the case if age, gender and education level are kept constant.
H3: We expect a reverse effect when CRT is replaced with FiI (Faith in Intuition): This means that a high FiI score correlates positively with the perceived accuracy of fake news and negatively with the perceived accuracy of real news. This is also the case if age, gender and educational level are kept constant.
H4: Opinion-consistent news is more likely to be perceived as real news, and opinion-inconsistent news more likely to be perceived as fake news. Neutral news is perceived equally well by everyone.
H5: We expect that the connection between cognitive ability measures and the distinction between fake and real news is mediated by perceived plausibility.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We have a 2 x 2 between-subject design with repeated measures.
Factor 1: news type – real vs. false
Factor 2: consistency to one’s ideology – consistent vs. inconsistent

q7.value: Presentation of fake and real news is randomized.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will not be recruited through advertisements, but through forwarding the survey to friends and family via social media (WhatsApp, Instagram) (convenience sampling). There will be no payment for participating. Participants must be at least 18 years old and will be parted into two groups, by questioning if they are either supporters or opponents of legalizing marihuana.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 100 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 120 assuming, that not all will complete the total task.

question.value: We manipulate the accuracy of the presented news, either its (actual) true or (actual) fake. Every participant reads 15 headlines, that are factually accurate (real news) and 15, that are entirely untrue (fake news). Five stories of each type were selected to be Marihuana-supporter-consistent, Marihuana-opponent-consistent, and politically neutral.

Measured variables will be the mean of perceived accuracy of fake and real news, the difference of these means and the plausability, as well as CRT, NfC and FiI. Accuracy will be measured on a 4-point scale from 1 = “not at all accurate” to 4 = “very accurate”). To account for plausibility, participants will be asked: „What ist the likelihood that the above headline is true?“ on a 7-point Likert Scale from 1 = „extremely unlikely“ to 7 = „extremely likely“

We will use a correlation analysis for H1 – H3, correlating the CRT, FiI and NfC scores with the perceived accuracy of fake and real news.
A repeated measure between subject ANOVA will be used to analyse H4. True and fake news (either consistent or inconsistent to the participant’s ideology) are the independent variables. The mean difference of perceived accuracy of true minus the fake news is the dependent variable. For H5 a mediation analysis will be performed, the correlation of cognitive abilities and ability to distinguish fake and real news, with the mediator plausibility.

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the correlation tests suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q21.value: If a subject does not complete the survey followed after every headline, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

attributes.title: Veganism and Gay Stereotypes
attributes.description: This study investigates the relationship between stereotypes of vegans and stereotypes of gay men. Participants will be randomly assigned to view the profile of either a vegan man or a control man, and will be asked to rate the target in the profile on a variety of traits related to socioeconomic status, femininity, masculinity, sexual orientation, and gay stereotypes.

q2.value: The purpose of this study is to investigate whether the vegan stereotype is associated with the stereotype of gay men, and by what mechanism. Participants will be randomly assigned to view a profile of a vegan or a control man. They will subsequently rate the man on stereotypical qualities associated with gay men, sexual orientation, socioeconomic status, femininity and masculinity. It is hypothesized that the vegan target will be rated higher than the control target on gay stereotypical qualities and will also be more likely to be assumed to be gay. It is further expected that the vegan target will be perceived to be higher is Socioeconomic status, be more feminine and less masculine than the control target. It is further predicted that the association between target diet and stereotypically gay qualities will be mediated by socioeconomic status, femininity and masculinity. In addition, the association between target diet and sexual orientation is hypothesized to also be mediated by socioeconomic status, femininity and masculinity.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Between subjects design with 1 factor (diet) and 2 levels (vegan and control)

q7.value: We will use Qualtrics software to randomize participants into one of two conditions (vegan or control).

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q9.value: Data collection has begun for this study (54 out of 150 participants have been recruited). Data analysis has not yet begun.

question.value:
Participants will be recruited from a small Northeastern public university as well as via social media (method of recruitment will be recorded in demographics but not analyzed). The link will be disseminated on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter, as well as flyers around campus.   Participants will receive 1 Introductory Psychology course credit or extra credit in courses that offer that option. All participants will also have the opportunity to be entered into a lottery for a chance to win a $25 Amazon gift card. The lottery will be collected in a separate survey and will not be linked to the data to maintain confidentiality.

Participants’ will be excluded from analyses if: 
• they indicate that they are vegetarian/vegan on a demographic question 
• Are less than 18 years old 
• Failed all of the manipulation checks 
• Did not complete the study or have many missing data points 
• Responses are overly consistent (same response to multiple questions) 
• Reaction time is excessively and unrealistically low (took less than 5 minutes to complete the study) 
• Indicated that they have previously completed the same study 
• We will conduct analyses with and without gay participants and will report both.
Participants will randomly be assigned into one of two conditions. They will either perceive a profile of a vegan or a control man.

The primary dependent variables are: gay stereotypical qualities, gay sexual orientation, socioeconomic status, masculinity and femininity. Participants will rate a target person on these dimensions on a 1 (“Way below average/Much less likely”) to 5 (“Way above average/Much more likely”) scale. 

Gay Stereotypical Qualities Scale. This 5-item scale was adapted from Petsko and Bodenhausen (2019) and includes the following items: “Talkative,” “Ostentatious and Showy,” “Pleasure-loving,” “Sexually Perverted,” and “Musical.” These items will be averaged to create a gay stereotypical qualities composite. This scale will be tested for reliability using Cronbach’s alpha. 

Gay Sexual orientation. This scale will consist of three subscales:

Attraction to men. Participants will estimate the likelihood that a male target is likely to “date men,” “identify as gay,” and “be attracted to men. These items will be averaged and Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated. 

Attraction to women. Participants will estimate the likelihood that a male target is likely to “date women,” “identify as straight,” and “be attracted to women.” These items will be averaged and Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated. 

Attraction to both women and men. Participants will estimate the likelihood that a male target is likely to “date women and men,” “identify as bi/pansexual,” and “be attracted to women and men.” 

Socioeconomic status. Socioeconomic status will be assessed with the following four items: “Own (rather than rent) his own home,” “Own luxury goods such as the latest technology,” “Financially secure and up to date on bills,” and “Have an advanced degree.” These items will be averaged to create a Socioeconomic status composite and Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated.  

Femininity. Femininity will be assessed with the six-item sub-scale for femininity, adapted from Carver, Vafei, Guerra, Freira, and Phillips (2013) and Bem (1974): “Warm,” “Gentle,” “Affectionate,” “Sympathetic,” “Sensitive,” and “Tender.” We included one additional item: “feminine” which was not in the original scale. A composite measure of femininity will be calculated by averaging responses to all seven items and Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated with and without the added item “femininity”. This item will be retained if it is found to be correlated with the rest of the items in the scale. 

Masculinity. will also be assessed with six-items adapted from Carver et al. (2013) and Bem (1974): “A Leader,” “Have a strong personality,” “Have leadership skills,” Dominant,” “Defends his beliefs,” and “Decisive.” We included one additional item: “masculine” which was not in the original scale.  A composite measure of masculinity will be calculated by averaging responses to all seven items and Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated with and without the added item “masculinity”. This item will be retained if it is found to be correlated with the rest of the items in the scale.

Five items (described above) will be combined to form the Gay Stereotypical Qualities composite.  This scale will be tested for reliability using Cronbach’s alpha.

Sexual orientation will be measured with three scales. Attraction to Men, Attraction to Women, and Attraction to Both Women and Men will each consist of three items. A series of one-way ANOVAS (vegan vs. control) will be used to test each of these items. If these analyses reveal that participants rated the vegan target as more likely to be attracted to men, less likely to be attracted to women and more likely to be attracted to men and women than the control target, we will combine these three attraction composites into a “gay sexual orientation” composite. We will average responses to the three attraction to men items, the three attraction to men and women items and the three attraction to women items (reversed scored). Higher scores on this scale will indicate a greater likelihood of being “attracted to men” or “men and women” than “women”. If only the “attraction to men” and “attraction to women” yield significant results (the “attraction to men and women” measure does not) then we will create a composite measure using only these two scales such that higher scores will indicate greater attraction to men than to women. We will calculate the Cronbach’s alpha reliability for this scale and if it is greater than 0.70 we will proceed to use this composite measure in the mediational analysis. 

Four items (described above) will be averaged to create a Socioeconomic Status composite and Cronbach's alpha will be calculated.

Seven items (described above) will be used to create a composite measure of femininity. A composite measure of femininity will be calculated by averaging responses to all seven items and Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated with and without the added item “femininity”. This item will be retained if it is found to be correlated with the rest of the items in the scale.

Seven items (described above) will be used to create a composite measure of masculinity. A composite measure of masculinity will be calculated by averaging responses to all seven items and Cronbach’s alpha will be calculated with and without the added item “masculinity”. This item will be retained if it is found to be correlated with the rest of the items in the scale.

We will conduct a series of one-way ANOVAS with condition (vegan vs. control) as the independent variable and the gay stereotypical qualities scale, attraction to men, attraction to women, attraction to women and men, socioeconomic status, femininity and masculinity as the dependent variables.  Composite measures will be assessed as described earlier.

If the results of the ANOVAs are significant and confirm our hypotheses that the vegan target will be more likely to be perceived as possessing stereotypically gay qualities, more likely to be perceived as having a gay sexual orientation, more likely to be perceived as being of high SES, more feminine an less masculine, we will proceed to conduct mediational analyses. We will treat socioeconomic status, femininity and masculinity as mediators of the association between condition and the gay stereotypical qualities scale and condition and gay sexual orientation scale. We will conduct mediational analyses using OLS regression with the Process macro for SPSS (Hayes 2018).

Steps 3-5 of the analysis plan above will be repeated along demographic lines to determine any undetected demographic effects. These would include the gender, vegan knowledge, LGBTQ+ knowledge, religion, sexual orientation, and socioeconomic status of the participant.

q19.value: We will use the standard p < .05 criteria for determining significance. Tests will be two-tailed unless otherwise specified.

registration_responses.q2: The purpose of this study is to investigate whether the vegan stereotype is associated with the stereotype of gay men, and by what mechanism. Participants will be randomly assigned to view a profile of a vegan or a control man. They will subsequently rate the man on stereotypical qualities associated with gay men, sexual orientation, socioeconomic status, femininity and masculinity. It is hypothesized that the vegan target will be rated higher than the control target on gay stereotypical qualities and will also be more likely to be assumed to be gay. It is further expected that the vegan target will be perceived to be higher is Socioeconomic status, be more feminine and less masculine than the control target. It is further predicted that the association between target diet and stereotypically gay qualities will be mediated by socioeconomic status, femininity and masculinity. In addition, the association between target diet and sexual orientation is hypothesized to also be mediated by socioeconomic status, femininity and masculinity.

attributes.title: Extrinisic Motivators for  individuals high in Dark Triad traits to accept undesirable tasks in the workplace.
attributes.description: Seeking correlations between extrinsic motivators and Dark Triad (D3) personality traits. We are using a modified Dark Triad Inventory (SD3) and a 9-item survey of undesirable task scenarios (UTS) paired with three categories of extrinsic motivators (prestige, promotion, and monetary) in a digital format to access participants. We anticipate seeing moderate correlations between extrinsic motivators and one of the three parts of the dark triad. This information may be useful to employers, HR departments, probation officers, and other fields associated with high D3 individuals.

q2.value: We anticipate seeing moderate correlations between extrinsic motivators and one of the three parts of the dark triad: Psychopathy - Monetary Reward, Narcissism – Prestige, and Machiavellianism – Promotion.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: In a Google Form, the SD3 Dark Triad Inventory, a 9- item questionnaire of undesirable task scenarios, and demographic information inventory will be combined into a 15-20-minute online survey. Data will be analyzed by comparing means of the SD3 categories (MV, PP, NC) and UTS (prestige, promotion, and monetary award) using a one-way analysis of variance ANOVA, hierarchal regression, and correlations analysis. Additionally, an item analysis, internal reliability of inventories, and other demographic correlations will be processed. Finally, we will examine trends of preferred motivator costs.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Survey will be open to the general public. Any participants that states their age is not within 18-64 limit will have their data removed. Form will be made available though Google Forms. Survey will posted on several social media platforms.

The Dark Triad (D3) consists of three personality traits: Narcissism (NC), Machiavellianism (MV), and Psychopathy (PP). Dark triad traits indicate extreme self-focus, calculated manipulation, and impulsive manipulation, respectively. The extrinsic motivators (EMs) prestige, promotion, and monetary award are defined as admiration based on the perception of one’s achievements, increase in workplace power, and cash bonuses, respectively.

Data will be analyzed by comparing means of the SD3 categories (MV, PP, NC) and UTS (prestige, promotion, and monetary award) using a one-way analysis of variance ANOVA, hierarchal regression, and correlations analysis. Additionally, an item analysis, internal reliability of inventories, and other demographic correlations will be processed. Finally, we will examine trends of preferred motivator costs.

attributes.title: Sensitivity of Japanese individuals to appearance and disappearance of facial expressions
attributes.description: Ishii et al. (2011) claimed that the Japanese individuals are highly sensitive to social signs of disapproval (such as the disappearance of happiness) compared to the Americans, because in their cultural contexts, where interdependence is prevalent, it is imperative that they adjust to their social environments. This claim was evidenced by the fact that the Japanese judged the offset of happiness earlier than the Americans, while observing individuals gradually changing their facial expressions from happiness to neutral. However, the pattern was not the same for sadness. The present study aims to conceptually replicate the previous findings, incorporating new conditions where sadness or happiness appears on a neutral face. Since the appearance of sadness in one’s face is also a sign (rather a more direct sign) of disapproval, we expect that the Japanese would judge the onset of sadness earlier than the onset of happiness.

q1.value: Asuka Komiya, Keiko Ogawa, Keiko Ishii, Atsunori Ariga, Tomoaki Osaki

q2.value:
1. We hypothesize that the Japanese individuals are highly sensitive to social signs of disapproval (i.e., the offset of happiness and the onset of sadness). This hypothesis predicts that the Japanese participants will judge the offset of happiness earlier than the offset of sadness when they watch individuals changing their facial expressions from happiness/sadness to neutral (a part of direct replication).

2. The hypothesis additionally predicts that the Japanese individuals will judge the onset of sadness earlier than the onset of happiness when they watch individuals changing their facial expressions from neutral to happiness/sadness due to their high sensitivity to others’ disapproval.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We have a within-subject 2 (facial expression: happiness and sadness) × 2 (ethnicity of face: Japanese and Caucasians) × 2 (judgment: offset and onset) factorial design.

q7.value: Participants will perform the judgment task in offset and onset conditions. The order of the conditions is counterbalanced across participants. In each condition, participants view 32 movie clips (i.e., 4 models × 2 genders [female and male] × 2 ethnicities [Japanese and Caucasian] × 2 facial expressions [happiness and sadness]), which are presented in a random order. The randomization is performed through a computer program (Inquisit).

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through advertisements in the first-year-seminar class. Their participation is completely voluntary. They will receive some snacks and a pen in exchange for their participation.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 24 participants.

q12.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect a large effect size (d = .80, Cohen, 1969) at the standard .05 alpha error probability. The effect size is estimated based on Ishii et al. (2011), which reported that the Japanese individuals judged the offset of smiles significantly earlier than they did sad expressions with a large effect size (d = 1.11). The analysis of this setting yields that at least 23 participants are needed to detect the effect (happiness vs sadness fading away). Thus, 24 participants are satisfactory to meet the counterbalance of conditions (as noted above).

q13.value: We will stop data collection when the sample size reaches 24 participants.

question.value:
1. We will manipulate the judgment (offset or onset) and facial expressions (happiness or sadness). Under an offset condition, the participants will view a movie clip in which an individual’s sad or happy face changes to neutral (i.e., sadness or happiness gradually fades). Then, they will be asked to indicate the point at which they think that the target no longer expresses the initial emotion. On the other hand, under an onset condition, the participants will be made to view a movie clip in which an individual’s neutral face changes to a sad or happy face (i.e., sadness or happiness gradually appears). Then, they will be asked to indicate the point at which they think that the target starts to express an emotion. 

2. In addition, the stimulus set includes a factor called ‘Ethnicity of Faces (Japanese or Caucasians).’ Since this project does not include a cross-cultural study unlike the previous research (Ishii et al., 2011), we may not need to include this factor. However, one of our aims is to examine whether we could replicate the previous findings. Therefore, we intend to use the same stimulus set as in the previous studies and include this factor in the analysis.
The single outcome variable will be the perceived offset/onset frames of facial expression.
N/A

We use a three-way within subject ANOVA to analyze our results. The manipulated, categorical independent variables are 'Judgement,' ‘Facial Expressions,’ and ‘Ethnicity of Faces,’ whereas the dependent variable is a frame number of the movie at which the participant judges an offset/onset of facial expression.

q18.value: The “onset/offset frame of facial expression” does not require any additional transformations.

q19.value: We use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. We will conduct t-tests for post-hoc comparisons.

q20.value: Following the procedure of Ishii et al. (2011), we exclude trials on which the judged offset/onset frames deviated over three standard deviations from the mean.

q21.value: Missing data is not be expected.

q22.value: We expect that certain demographic traits and individual characteristics may be related to the onset/offset judgment of others’ facial expressions. Therefore, we look for relationships between demographic variables (gender, moving experiences, and living status), as well as individual characteristics (relational mobility and anxious attachment), and the onset/offset frames of facial expressions.

q23.value:
Literature

Ishii, K., Miyamoto, Y., Mayama, K. & Niedenthal, P. M. (2011). When your smiles fades away: Cultural differences in sensitivity to the disappearance of smiles. Social Psychological and Personality Science, 2(5), 516-522.

Neidential, P. M., Halberstadt, J. B., Margolin, J., & Innes-Ker, A. H. (2000). Emotional state and the detection of change in facial expression of emotion. European Journal of Social Psychology, 30, 211-222.

registration_responses.q7: Participants will perform the judgment task in offset and onset conditions. The order of the conditions is counterbalanced across participants. In each condition, participants view 32 movie clips (i.e., 4 models × 2 genders [female and male] × 2 ethnicities [Japanese and Caucasian] × 2 facial expressions [happiness and sadness]), which are presented in a random order. The randomization is performed through a computer program (Inquisit).
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q11: Our target sample size is 24 participants.
registration_responses.q12: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect a large effect size (d = .80, Cohen, 1969) at the standard .05 alpha error probability. The effect size is estimated based on Ishii et al. (2011), which reported that the Japanese individuals judged the offset of smiles significantly earlier than they did sad expressions with a large effect size (d = 1.11). The analysis of this setting yields that at least 23 participants are needed to detect the effect (happiness vs sadness fading away). Thus, 24 participants are satisfactory to meet the counterbalance of conditions (as noted above).
registration_responses.q13: We will stop data collection when the sample size reaches 24 participants.
registration_responses.q18: The “onset/offset frame of facial expression” does not require any additional transformations.
registration_responses.q19: We use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. We will conduct t-tests for post-hoc comparisons.
registration_responses.q20: Following the procedure of Ishii et al. (2011), we exclude trials on which the judged offset/onset frames deviated over three standard deviations from the mean.
registration_responses.q21: Missing data is not be expected.
registration_responses.q22: We expect that certain demographic traits and individual characteristics may be related to the onset/offset judgment of others’ facial expressions. Therefore, we look for relationships between demographic variables (gender, moving experiences, and living status), as well as individual characteristics (relational mobility and anxious attachment), and the onset/offset frames of facial expressions.
registration_responses.q23:
Literature

Ishii, K., Miyamoto, Y., Mayama, K. & Niedenthal, P. M. (2011). When your smiles fades away: Cultural differences in sensitivity to the disappearance of smiles. Social Psychological and Personality Science, 2(5), 516-522.

Neidential, P. M., Halberstadt, J. B., Margolin, J., & Innes-Ker, A. H. (2000). Emotional state and the detection of change in facial expression of emotion. European Journal of Social Psychology, 30, 211-222.
registration_responses.q6.question: We have a within-subject 2 (facial expression: happiness and sadness) × 2 (ethnicity of face: Japanese and Caucasians) × 2 (judgment: offset and onset) factorial design.
registration_responses.q10.question: Participants will be recruited through advertisements in the first-year-seminar class. Their participation is completely voluntary. They will receive some snacks and a pen in exchange for their participation.
registration_responses.q14.question:
1. We will manipulate the judgment (offset or onset) and facial expressions (happiness or sadness). Under an offset condition, the participants will view a movie clip in which an individual’s sad or happy face changes to neutral (i.e., sadness or happiness gradually fades). Then, they will be asked to indicate the point at which they think that the target no longer expresses the initial emotion. On the other hand, under an onset condition, the participants will be made to view a movie clip in which an individual’s neutral face changes to a sad or happy face (i.e., sadness or happiness gradually appears). Then, they will be asked to indicate the point at which they think that the target starts to express an emotion. 

2. In addition, the stimulus set includes a factor called ‘Ethnicity of Faces (Japanese or Caucasians).’ Since this project does not include a cross-cultural study unlike the previous research (Ishii et al., 2011), we may not need to include this factor. However, one of our aims is to examine whether we could replicate the previous findings. Therefore, we intend to use the same stimulus set as in the previous studies and include this factor in the analysis.
registration_responses.q15.question: The single outcome variable will be the perceived offset/onset frames of facial expression.
registration_responses.q16.question: N/A
registration_responses.q17.question: We use a three-way within subject ANOVA to analyze our results. The manipulated, categorical independent variables are 'Judgement,' ‘Facial Expressions,’ and ‘Ethnicity of Faces,’ whereas the dependent variable is a frame number of the movie at which the participant judges an offset/onset of facial expression.
